source: Natenberg - Option Volatility and Pricing (Advanced Trading Strategies and Techniques)
description: Comprehensive knowledge base from Sheldon Natenberg's seminal work on options trading, volatility analysis, and risk management - structured for RAG retrieval

chunks.topic: Historical vs Implied Volatility - Core Concepts
chunks.content: Historical volatility (HV) measures the actual price movement of an underlying asset over a past period, calculated as the annualized standard deviation of returns. It answers 'How much did the stock actually move?' Implied volatility (IV) is derived from option prices and represents the market's expectation of future volatility. It answers 'How much does the market expect the stock to move?' The critical insight is that IV is forward-looking while HV is backward-looking. When IV > HV, options are relatively expensive (market expects more movement than history suggests). When IV < HV, options are relatively cheap. Professional traders constantly compare these metrics. A stock with 20% HV but 35% IV presents a potential volatility selling opportunity - you can sell options at inflated prices. Conversely, 40% HV with 25% IV suggests buying options cheaply before the market reprices volatility higher. The relationship between HV and IV is mean-reverting over time, though the timeframe varies by underlying. Technology stocks often show higher IV due to event risk (earnings, product launches), while stable dividend-paying stocks show compressed IV ranges. Understanding this relationship is fundamental to all option strategies.
key_formulas: Historical Volatility = StdDev(Daily Returns) × √252
Daily Return = ln(Price_today / Price_yesterday)
IV is solved from Black-Scholes: Market Price = BS_Price(S, K, T, r, IV)
practical_rules: Calculate HV over multiple periods (10-day, 20-day, 60-day) to see volatility trends
Compare current IV to its own 52-week range (IV percentile) not just to HV
Use IV rank: (Current IV - 52w Low IV) / (52w High IV - 52w Low IV) × 100
Sell premium when IV > 70th percentile, buy premium when IV < 30th percentile
Always check both metrics before entering volatility trades
risk_warnings: IV can remain elevated longer than you can remain solvent (don't fade high IV blindly)
Past volatility doesn't guarantee future volatility - structural changes occur
Earnings events, FDA approvals, elections cause IV spikes that may be justified
Low HV can explode into high HV overnight - never assume stability will persist

chunks.content: Volatility term structure shows how implied volatility varies across different expirations for the same underlying. Near-term options often have different IV than longer-dated options, creating a volatility curve. A 'normal' term structure slopes upward (longer-dated options have higher IV) because there's more uncertainty over longer periods. An inverted term structure (near-term IV > long-term IV) typically signals an imminent event: earnings in 2 weeks, FDA decision pending, election approaching. This inversion creates calendar spread opportunities. Volatility cones display historical volatility ranges across multiple timeframes (10-day HV, 20-day HV, 30-day HV, etc.) showing how volatility behaves at different measurement periods. By plotting current IV against the HV cone, traders identify rich or cheap options. If 30-day IV is at the 90th percentile of the 30-day HV cone, options are historically expensive. The cone reveals volatility clustering - high volatility periods tend to cluster together, as do low volatility periods. Professional traders use cones to set realistic expectations: if 20-day HV rarely exceeds 40%, selling options with 50% IV offers edge. The term structure and cone together provide a complete volatility framework.
key_formulas: Term Structure: Plot IV(30d), IV(60d), IV(90d), IV(180d)
HV Cone: Calculate HV over rolling 10-day, 20-day, 30-day, 60-day windows
Percentile Rank: % of time current IV is below historical IV readings
practical_rules: Inverted term structure → Buy calendar spreads (sell front month, buy back month)
Normal steep upward slope → Sell calendar spreads or diagonals
IV > 80th percentile of HV cone → Strong sell premium signal
IV < 20th percentile of HV cone → Strong buy premium signal
Compare same-expiration IVs to detect volatility skew opportunities
risk_warnings: Term structure can invert rapidly before known events - don't fight it
Calendar spreads lose if volatility structure changes against you
HV cones based on past data - unprecedented events create new regimes
Front-month options experience rapid IV decay post-event - timing critical

chunks.topic: Mean Reversion of Volatility - Trading Principle
chunks.content: Volatility exhibits mean-reverting behavior - periods of high volatility tend to revert to average levels, and periods of low volatility eventually expand. This is one of the most reliable phenomena in options trading. During market stress, VIX spikes to 40-80, but historically reverts to its long-term mean around 15-20 within weeks or months. Individual stock IVs behave similarly. The mean reversion principle underlies most premium selling strategies. When IV spikes, sell premium expecting reversion to mean. When IV is compressed, buy premium expecting expansion. The key is identifying the 'true mean' for each underlying - it varies significantly. SPY has a stable mean around 15-18% IV. Tech stocks might have means around 35-50%. Meme stocks have higher, more unstable means. The reversion speed also varies: broad market IV (VIX) reverts faster than individual stock IV. Small-cap IVs are stickier than large-cap. Earnings-driven spikes collapse immediately post-announcement. The practical edge comes from selling IV when it's 2+ standard deviations above its mean, and buying when it's 2+ standard deviations below. However, regime changes do occur - the 2008 crisis permanently elevated baseline volatility for years.
key_formulas: IV Mean = Average(IV) over lookback period (typically 252 trading days)
IV Z-Score = (Current IV - Mean IV) / StdDev(IV)
Reversion Signal: |Z-Score| > 2.0
practical_rules: Sell premium when IV Z-score > +2.0 (volatility extremely elevated)
Buy premium when IV Z-score < -2.0 (volatility extremely compressed)
Use at least 1-year lookback period to calculate stable mean
Adjust position sizing inversely to IV - larger positions at extreme IVs
Exit volatility trades when IV reverts to within 0.5 standard deviations of mean
risk_warnings: Black swan events create new volatility regimes - mean can shift permanently
Time to reversion varies wildly - can take months, causing margin pressure
Volatility can spike higher before reverting - stop losses essential
Structural changes (new regulations, industry disruption) invalidate historical means

chunks.content: Delta measures an option's price sensitivity to $1 moves in the underlying. A call with 0.60 delta gains $0.60 when the stock rises $1. Delta also approximates probability of finishing in-the-money: 0.30 delta ≈ 30% chance of expiring ITM. Call deltas range from 0 to 1.00; put deltas from 0 to -1.00. At-the-money (ATM) options have ~0.50 delta. Deep in-the-money (ITM) options approach 1.00 delta, behaving almost like stock. Far out-of-the-money (OTM) options have deltas near 0, moving minimally with stock price. Delta is the foundation of directional trading and hedging. A delta-neutral portfolio has zero directional exposure - gains from stock price moves are offset by option positions. Market makers maintain delta-neutral positions, profiting from volatility and time decay rather than directional bets. For retail traders, delta determines position sizing: 100 shares of stock = 1.00 delta per share = 100 total delta. One ATM call (~0.50 delta) = ~50 shares of stock exposure. To replicate 100 shares, buy 2 ATM calls. Delta changes as stock price moves (gamma effect) and as time passes, requiring continuous monitoring and adjustment for hedged positions.
key_formulas: Delta_call ≈ N(d1) in Black-Scholes, ranges [0, 1]
Delta_put ≈ N(d1) - 1, ranges [-1, 0]
Portfolio Delta = Σ(Quantity × Delta × Multiplier)
Hedge Ratio = -Portfolio Delta / Stock Delta
practical_rules: ATM options (0.45-0.55 delta) provide balanced risk/reward for directional trades
Use 0.70-0.80 delta options as stock replacement for capital efficiency
Delta-neutral strategies: sell ATM straddle, buy OTM protection
Rebalance delta when position moves >10 deltas from target
Near expiration, delta accelerates toward 0 or 1.00 - manage gamma risk
risk_warnings: Delta is dynamic, not static - changes constantly with price and time
Large price moves create delta exposure even in 'neutral' positions
Low-delta OTM options can quickly gain delta if stock moves favorably
Earnings/events can cause gap moves that blow through delta hedges

chunks.content: Gamma measures the rate of change of delta. If delta is speed, gamma is acceleration. High gamma means delta changes rapidly as the stock moves. ATM options have maximum gamma; deep ITM and OTM options have minimal gamma. Gamma is highest near expiration - weekly options have explosive gamma risk/opportunity. Long gamma positions (long options) benefit from large price swings in either direction because delta adjusts favorably. If you're long a 0.50 delta call with 0.10 gamma and stock rises $1, your new delta is 0.60 - you profit more on the next $1 move. Short gamma positions (short options) suffer from large moves because delta adjusts against you. This is why selling options is called 'picking up pennies in front of a steamroller.' Gamma scalping is a professional strategy: maintain delta-neutral position while long gamma, profit from volatility by continuously rehedging. When stock rises, sell shares to rebalance delta (sell high). When stock falls, buy shares to rebalance (buy low). The continuous rebalancing profits from volatility regardless of direction, but costs theta (time decay). Gamma peaks at ATM and explodes approaching expiration - Friday afternoon gamma in weekly options creates wild price action.
key_formulas: Gamma = ∂Delta / ∂Stock Price
New Delta = Old Delta + (Gamma × Stock Price Change)
Gamma_call = Gamma_put for same strike (Black-Scholes)
Maximum Gamma occurs at ATM, decays toward 0 as you move away
practical_rules: Buy gamma (long options) when expecting big moves or high volatility
Sell gamma (short options) when expecting range-bound, low volatility
Gamma scalp ATM straddles when realized vol > implied vol
Avoid short gamma into known events (earnings, FDA, elections)
Near expiration, gamma risk explodes - reduce position size or close early
risk_warnings: Short gamma can create unlimited losses in gap moves (overnight risk)
Gamma scalping requires constant monitoring and frequent trading (costs add up)
Weekend gamma can't be hedged - Friday close to Monday open gap risk
Gamma and theta are inversely related - long gamma pays theta, short gamma earns theta

chunks.content: Theta measures the rate of time decay - how much option value erodes each day, all else equal. Theta is the 'rent' for holding an option position. Long options are short theta (you pay rent daily). Short options are long theta (you collect rent daily). Theta accelerates as expiration approaches - weekly options decay faster than monthlies, which decay faster than LEAPS. The last 30 days see exponential theta decay, with the final week experiencing brutal erosion. ATM options have the highest theta in absolute dollar terms. Deep ITM options have minimal theta because they're mostly intrinsic value. OTM options have theta but less dollar impact. Theta is often called the option seller's edge - collect decay every day the market is closed, every weekend, every holiday. A 30-day ATM option with -$15 theta loses $15/day (all else equal). Over a weekend, 3 days of theta vanish. Premium sellers structure trades to maximize theta collection while managing other Greeks. The classic theta trade is short ATM iron condor - collect maximum time decay while capping directional risk. The relationship between theta and gamma is fundamental: you can't be long both simultaneously. Long gamma costs theta; short gamma earns theta.
key_formulas: Theta = ∂Option Price / ∂Time (typically shown as negative for long options)
Portfolio Theta = Σ(Quantity × Theta × Multiplier)
Theta/Gamma relationship: High gamma ↔ High theta
practical_rules: Sell theta when IV is elevated (collect more premium per day of decay)
Target 30-45 DTE for optimal theta/gamma balance in credit spreads
Close winners early at 50% max profit - theta decay is non-linear
Avoid holding short-term options through weekends unless collecting premium
Scale position size by theta - don't overexpose to time decay risk
risk_warnings: Theta is 'all else equal' - volatility spikes can overwhelm theta gains
Weekend theta can't offset gap risk - Friday to Monday disasters happen
Over-optimizing for theta can create excessive gamma/vega risk
Last week theta acceleration can reverse in hours if volatility explodes

chunks.content: Vega measures an option's price sensitivity to 1% changes in implied volatility. If an option has $25 vega and IV increases from 30% to 31%, the option gains $25 in value. Long options are long vega (profit from IV increases). Short options are short vega (profit from IV decreases). ATM options have maximum vega. Longer-dated options have higher vega than near-term options because volatility has more time to impact price. This creates the foundation for calendar spreads: sell near-term low-vega options, buy long-term high-vega options, profit if IV expands. Vega is critical for earnings trades: IV typically inflates 2-3 weeks before earnings, then crashes immediately after (volatility crush). Buying options into earnings faces massive negative vega post-announcement even if you're directionally correct. Conversely, selling options into earnings captures inflated vega, profiting from the crush. Professional traders isolate vega exposure using vega-neutral spreads - combining long and short positions to neutralize volatility risk while expressing other views (direction, time decay). Understanding vega separates amateurs from professionals: amateurs focus only on direction, professionals manage volatility exposure explicitly.
key_formulas: Vega = ∂Option Price / ∂Implied Volatility
Portfolio Vega = Σ(Quantity × Vega × Multiplier)
Vega_call = Vega_put for same strike and expiration
practical_rules: Buy vega (long options) when IV is below 30th percentile and trending up
Sell vega (short options) when IV is above 70th percentile and trending down
Use calendar spreads to go long vega while minimizing theta cost
Avoid buying options 1-2 weeks before earnings (IV inflation priced in)
Sell options 1-2 days before earnings to capture volatility crush
risk_warnings: Vega can collapse 30-50% overnight after earnings - timing is critical
Market-wide volatility events (VIX spikes) impact all positions simultaneously
Long vega strategies bleed theta while waiting for volatility - time limit exists
Vega exposure compounds across positions - portfolio-level vega can be hidden

chunks.content: Rho measures an option's sensitivity to interest rate changes. It's the least discussed Greek because interest rates change slowly compared to stock prices, time, and volatility. However, during Fed rate hiking/cutting cycles or for long-dated options (LEAPS), rho becomes material. Higher interest rates increase call values and decrease put values. Why? In Black-Scholes, buying a call is economically similar to buying stock on margin - you pay the option premium instead of borrowing to buy stock. Higher rates make this synthetic long stock position more attractive (you save more on interest costs), increasing call value. For puts, the reverse holds. Rho is proportional to time to expiration - LEAPS have significant rho while weekly options have negligible rho. In a rising rate environment, long-term call spreads benefit relative to put spreads. Professional traders mostly ignore rho for short-term trades but must account for it in long-term portfolios. The 2022-2023 Fed hiking cycle made rho relevant again after a decade of zero rates. A 1% rate increase might add $0.10-0.15 to a 1-year ATM call on a $100 stock - not huge but meaningful in size.
key_formulas: Rho = ∂Option Price / ∂Interest Rate
Rho_call is positive (calls benefit from higher rates)
Rho_put is negative (puts hurt by higher rates)
Rho scales with time to expiration and stock price
practical_rules: Ignore rho for options <60 days to expiration in stable rate environments
Consider rho for LEAPS (>1 year) or during Fed policy shift periods
In rising rate environment, slightly favor call spreads over put spreads
Adjust long-term option valuations by 0.05-0.10 per 1% rate change
Portfolio rho matters for large option books - calculate and monitor
risk_warnings: Surprise Fed decisions can create immediate rho P/L swings
Rho interacts with delta for synthetic positions - watch combined exposure
Long-term options have rho risk but it's usually dominated by vega risk
In crisis scenarios, rate cuts happen rapidly - LEAP puts can suffer

chunks.content: The Black-Scholes model revolutionized options pricing but has critical assumptions that are violated in real markets. Assumptions: (1) Stock returns are log-normally distributed - reality: fat tails, crashes happen more than normal distribution predicts. (2) Volatility is constant - reality: volatility changes constantly, creating vega risk. (3) No transaction costs - reality: spreads, commissions, slippage matter. (4) Continuous trading possible - reality: gaps happen, especially overnight and weekends. (5) No dividends (standard model) - reality: dividends impact early exercise decisions. (6) European exercise only - reality: American options can be exercised early. Despite these limitations, Black-Scholes provides a consistent framework for pricing and comparing options. The key insight: use it as a common language, not absolute truth. Implied volatility is the 'fudge factor' that makes Black-Scholes match market prices despite wrong assumptions. The model assumes constant volatility, but by solving for IV we capture the market's collective judgment about future volatility. Professionals use Black-Scholes for Greeks calculations and relative value analysis, but overlay real-world adjustments: volatility smiles for crash risk, early exercise analysis for American options, dividend adjustments.
key_formulas: C = S×N(d1) - K×e^(-rT)×N(d2)
d2 = d1 - σ√T
Where: S=stock, K=strike, T=time, r=rate, σ=volatility, N=cumulative normal
practical_rules: Use Black-Scholes for Greeks calculations and theoretical value comparisons
Don't trust absolute prices - focus on relative value between strikes/expirations
Adjust for American vs European exercise - use binomial for American options
Account for dividends explicitly - they significantly impact ITM calls and early exercise
Recognize the model underprices tail risk - add safety margin for short OTM options
risk_warnings: Model assumes no gaps - overnight/weekend risk is underestimated
Fat tails mean OTM options are systematically underpriced by Black-Scholes
Constant volatility assumption creates vega risk not captured in model
Early exercise of American options (especially puts) invalidates European model pricing

chunks.topic: Binomial Model - American Options and Early Exercise
chunks.content: The binomial model prices American options by modeling discrete price paths over time steps. Unlike Black-Scholes (European, single forward calculation), binomial works backward from expiration, checking at each node whether early exercise is optimal. This is critical for American puts on dividend-paying stocks and deep ITM calls before ex-dividend. The model assumes at each time step, price moves up or down by fixed factors (u and d), creating a tree of possibilities. At expiration, option value is intrinsic value (max(S-K, 0) for calls). Working backward, at each node: option value = max(intrinsic value, expected discounted value from waiting). If intrinsic > expected, early exercise is optimal. Why early exercise matters: (1) Deep ITM puts may be exercised early to capture interest on proceeds rather than wait. (2) ITM calls may be exercised just before ex-dividend to capture the dividend rather than suffer the stock price drop. (3) During takeovers, calls on acquired companies may be exercised immediately. More time steps = more accurate pricing but slower computation. Professional traders use 50-100 steps for accurate American option pricing. Retail traders can use online calculators or approximations.
key_formulas: u = e^(σ√Δt), d = 1/u (up and down factors)
p = (e^(rΔt) - d) / (u - d) (risk-neutral probability)
Option Value = max(Intrinsic, e^(-rΔt) × [p×Value_up + (1-p)×Value_down])
Early Exercise if: Intrinsic > Expected Discounted Value
practical_rules: Use binomial (not Black-Scholes) for American puts on dividend stocks
Check early exercise risk for deep ITM calls before ex-dividend dates
For European options, Black-Scholes is faster and accurate enough
Use at least 50 time steps for accurate American option pricing
If short ITM options near ex-dividend, be prepared for early assignment
risk_warnings: Early exercise can happen anytime - monitor ITM short positions closely
Dividends create sudden early exercise risk for call sellers
Deep ITM puts may be exercised early in high interest rate environments
Assignment on short options creates overnight stock position - margin risk

chunks.content: Put-call parity is the fundamental relationship between call, put, stock, and bond prices. For European options: C - P = S - K×e^(-rT). This means: long call + short put = synthetic long stock at strike K. Or: long stock + long put = long call + bond (protective put = fiduciary call). If this relationship is violated, arbitrage exists. Example: If C - P > S - PV(K), calls are overpriced or puts are underpriced relative to parity → sell calls, buy puts, buy stock, borrow at risk-free rate. Lock in riskless profit. In liquid markets, arbitrageurs enforce put-call parity to within bid-ask spreads. However, violations appear: (1) American options can violate due to early exercise value. (2) Hard-to-borrow stocks create 'short rebate' that shifts parity. (3) Dividends during option life require adjustments. (4) Illiquid strikes may show temporary violations. Professional traders use parity to create synthetic positions cheaply: if calls are expensive, create synthetic calls via put + stock. If hard to borrow stock for shorting, create synthetic short via long put + short call. Understanding parity also reveals conversion/reversal arbitrage strategies used by market makers.
key_formulas: Put-Call Parity (European): C - P = S - K×e^(-rT)
Rearranged: C = P + S - K×e^(-rT)
Synthetic Long Stock: Long Call + Short Put at same strike
Synthetic Call: Long Put + Long Stock
practical_rules: Check parity before entering spreads - sometimes synthetic is cheaper
If calls seem expensive, create synthetic calls (put + stock) instead
Use synthetic short stock (long put + short call) if stock is hard to borrow
Monitor parity violations in illiquid options - arbitrage opportunities exist
Adjust parity formula for dividends: subtract PV(dividends) from stock price
risk_warnings: American options violate parity due to early exercise - use binomial model
Synthetic positions have different margin requirements than outright
Hard-to-borrow stocks have 'negative rebate' that affects parity economics
Assignment risk on short option leg can disrupt synthetic position

chunks.topic: Trading the Volatility Smile and Skew
chunks.content: The volatility smile/skew shows that OTM puts trade at higher implied volatility than ATM options, while OTM calls trade at lower IV. This violates Black-Scholes assumption of constant volatility across strikes. The skew reflects market crash fear - investors pay up for downside protection (OTM puts) and discount upside participation (OTM calls). In equity markets, the skew is pronounced: 25-delta puts might have 20% higher IV than ATM. In currency markets, the smile is more symmetric. The skew creates trading opportunities: (1) Put vertical spreads are 'expensive' - buying OTM put costs more vega than selling further OTM put gains. (2) Put ratio spreads can exploit this - sell 2 OTM puts, buy 1 ATM put to be vega neutral. (3) Call vertical spreads are 'cheap' - selling OTM call gives up little vega compared to buying ATM call. Skew changes dynamically: flattens during calm markets, steepens during stress. Trading the skew means taking positions that profit from skew flattening or steepening independent of absolute volatility level. Advanced strategy: sell steep skew (collect OTM put premium), hedge with long ATM straddle to isolate skew exposure.
key_formulas: Skew = IV(25-delta put) - IV(ATM) - IV(25-delta call)
Skew Steepness = [IV(OTM put) - IV(ATM)] / Strike Distance
Vega-Neutral Ratio = Vega(Long) / Vega(Short)
practical_rules: Steep skew (high crash fear) → Sell OTM put verticals, buy call spreads
Flat skew (complacent market) → Buy OTM put protection cheaply
Use put ratio spreads (buy 1 ATM, sell 2 OTM) when skew is extremely steep
Monitor skew changes as leading indicator of market stress
Skew typically steepens into earnings/events - trade accordingly
risk_warnings: Skew can steepen rapidly in crashes - being short skew is dangerous
Ratio spreads have undefined risk if market crashes through short strikes
Skew mean-reversion is slower than overall volatility mean-reversion
Post-crash, elevated skew can persist for months or years

chunks.topic: Straddles and Strangles - Pure Volatility Plays
chunks.content: Straddles and strangles are non-directional strategies that profit from volatility, not direction. Long straddle = buy ATM call + ATM put at same strike and expiration. Profit if stock moves significantly in either direction. Maximum loss is total premium paid (if stock stays exactly at strike). Break-even points are strike ± premium paid. Long strangle = buy OTM call + OTM put. Cheaper than straddle (lower premium) but requires larger move to profit. Strangles have wider break-even range. When to use: (1) Long straddle/strangle before unknown binary events (FDA approval, earnings surprise) if IV is not yet elevated. (2) Short straddle/strangle in high IV environments expecting mean reversion and range-bound price action. Short straddles collect maximum theta but have unlimited risk in both directions - extremely dangerous without hedges. Iron condor is a hedged short strangle (sell strangle, buy wider protective wings). The key decision: is realized volatility likely to exceed implied volatility? If yes, buy straddle. If no, sell straddle (or safer: iron condor). Timing matters: buy volatility 2-3 weeks before event while IV is still cheap, sell 1-2 days before when IV peaks.
key_formulas: Long Straddle P/L = (|S_final - K| - Premium Paid) × 100
Break-even Points = K ± Total Premium Paid
Max Loss (long) = Total Premium Paid
Max Loss (short) = Unlimited
practical_rules: Buy straddles when IV < 30th percentile and binary event approaching
Sell straddles/iron condors when IV > 70th percentile with no events imminent
Use strangles for lower cost but set wider profit targets
Close long straddles 1-2 days before event to capture IV inflation
Never hold naked short straddles through earnings/events
risk_warnings: Long straddles decay rapidly - need large move quickly to profit
Volatility crush post-event can destroy long straddles even if directionally right
Short straddles have unlimited loss potential - use iron condors instead
Weekend risk: Friday close to Monday open gaps can devastate short straddles

chunks.content: Calendar spreads (time spreads) involve selling a near-term option and buying a longer-term option at the same strike, profiting from differential time decay and volatility changes. Typically: sell 30-day option, buy 60-90 day option. The near-term option decays faster (higher theta), while the long-term option has higher vega. Calendars are inherently long vega, long theta (you collect more theta than you pay, and benefit from volatility increases). They profit in three scenarios: (1) Stock stays near strike - maximize theta differential. (2) Implied volatility increases - long option gains more than short loses. (3) Term structure flattens - if near-term IV drops relative to long-term. Ideal setup: sell during elevated IV (collect high premium on front month), buy back month when IV is normal. As front month decays and IV potentially contracts, the spread widens. Risk: large directional moves hurt calendars because they're vega-positive but gamma-negative. If stock moves too far, both options go OTM or ITM and spread collapses. Diagonal spreads (calendar with different strikes) add directional bias. Professional traders use calendars to isolate volatility bets while minimizing directional risk.
key_formulas: Calendar Spread Value = Long Option Value - Short Option Value
Max Profit = Typically occurs at strike price at front month expiration
Theta_calendar = Theta_long - Theta_short (usually positive)
Vega_calendar = Vega_long - Vega_short (usually positive)
practical_rules: Enter calendars when IV is elevated (sell expensive near-term premium)
Use ATM strikes for maximum theta capture and vega exposure
Target 30-45 DTE for short leg, 60-90 DTE for long leg
Close when front month has 7-10 days left (gamma risk increases)
Roll short leg at 21 DTE if trade is profitable
risk_warnings: Large moves in either direction hurt calendars - stay near strike
Earnings/events can cause term structure changes that collapse spread
Early assignment on short leg creates naked long position - monitor ITM risk
Vega can work against you if term structure inverts unexpectedly

chunks.content: Professional position sizing uses Greeks to normalize risk across different option strategies. A 10-lot iron condor has different risk profile than a 10-lot long call, so sizing by number of contracts is meaningless. Instead, size by: (1) Delta exposure - limit total portfolio delta to prevent excessive directional risk. Conservative: keep portfolio delta within ±100 (equivalent to ±100 shares). Aggressive: ±500. (2) Theta exposure - if you're theta positive (premium seller), limit daily theta to amount you're willing to lose to volatility spike. Example: if portfolio collects $100/day theta, ensure you can withstand 5x reversal ($500 loss from vol spike). (3) Vega exposure - critical for volatility traders. Limit vega to percent of portfolio. Conservative: vega < 1% of account value per 1% IV change. (4) Gamma exposure - massive gamma (positive or negative) creates instability. Keep absolute gamma < 5% of delta. The key insight: normalize all positions to 'shares equivalent' using delta, then check that theta, vega, gamma are proportional to account size. A $10,000 account shouldn't have $500/day theta - that's 5% daily return requirement. A $100,000 account can handle it.
key_formulas: Risk-Adjusted Size = (Risk Capital × Risk %) / Greeks Exposure
Delta Limit = Account Value × Delta Risk % / Stock Price
Theta Limit = Account Value × Daily Risk % / Days
Vega Limit = Account Value × Volatility Risk %
practical_rules: Keep portfolio delta < 5% of account value in stock equivalent
Limit daily theta to 0.1-0.2% of account value (max daily collection)
Keep absolute vega < 2% of account value per 1% IV change
Monitor gamma: if |gamma/delta| > 0.05, position is too explosive
Scale position size inversely to volatility - smaller size in high IV
risk_warnings: Concentrated positions can have hidden Greeks exposure - calculate portfolio level
Correlated underlyings create multiplied Greeks - treat as single position
Near expiration, gamma explodes - reduce size significantly in last week
Stop losses based on Greeks, not just P/L - exit if delta/vega exceed limits

chunks.content: Managing a portfolio of option positions requires aggregating Greeks across all positions to understand total exposure. Individual position Greeks don't reveal portfolio risk - two positions might offset, or compound. Calculate portfolio Greeks by summing: Portfolio_Delta = Σ(Position_i Delta × Quantity × Multiplier). Same for gamma, theta, vega, rho. The result shows net exposure. Example: long 10 SPY calls (delta 0.50 each) + short 5 SPY puts (delta -0.30 each) = (10 × 0.50 × 100) + (5 × -0.30 × 100) = 500 - 150 = +350 net delta (equivalent to 350 shares long). Portfolio vega reveals volatility risk across all positions. High positive vega (long premium) means portfolio profits if IV rises, loses if IV falls. High negative vega (short premium) is the reverse. Professional traders target specific portfolio Greeks profiles: (1) Market makers: delta neutral, gamma neutral, collect theta. (2) Volatility traders: delta neutral, high vega (long or short), some gamma. (3) Directional option traders: significant delta, managed vega and theta. The key is intentionality - know your Greeks exposures and ensure they match your strategy.
key_formulas: Portfolio_Greek = Σ(Position_i_Greek × Quantity × Multiplier)
For spreads: Net Greek = Long_leg_Greek - Short_leg_Greek
Beta-Weighted Greeks: Convert all positions to SPY-equivalent for comparison
practical_rules: Calculate portfolio Greeks daily, especially before market open
Use beta-weighting to normalize different underlyings to common benchmark
Target delta neutral if you're volatility trading, not directional trading
Monitor vega concentration - don't have all vega in one underlying
Stress test: recalculate Greeks assuming ±10% stock move, ±20% IV change
risk_warnings: Correlation risk: positions in correlated stocks compound Greeks exposure
Sector concentration: multiple positions in same sector magnify risk
Event risk: earnings in multiple holdings same day multiplies volatility risk
Greeks change continuously - daily recalculation may miss intraday explosions

chunks.content: Stress testing reveals how your portfolio performs under extreme scenarios beyond normal Greeks analysis. Standard stress tests: (1) Stock price shocks: +/-10%, +/-20%, +/-30% instant moves. (2) Volatility shocks: IV doubles, IV halves, term structure inverts. (3) Time decay: fast forward 1 week, 2 weeks, to expiration. (4) Combined shocks: stock drops 20% AND IV spikes 50% (crash scenario). Use option pricing models to revalue entire portfolio under each scenario. This exposes risks that Greeks alone miss. Example: a position might be delta neutral currently (Greeks say 'balanced'), but stress test reveals if stock drops 15%, you lose $5,000 because gamma/vega interactions create convexity. The key scenarios to test: (1) Market crash: -20% stock, +100% IV. (2) Melt-up: +15% stock, -30% IV. (3) Grinding theta: stock flat, -10% IV per week. (4) Gap risk: overnight +/-5% move. Professional traders stress test before entering positions and daily during holding period. If any scenario creates unacceptable loss, don't take the trade or adjust position sizing.
key_formulas: Stress P/L = Revalue(Portfolio, S×shock_factor, IV×shock_factor, T-time_decay) - Current Value
Greeks-based approximation: ΔP/L ≈ Delta×ΔS + Gamma×(ΔS)²/2 + Vega×ΔIV + Theta×Δt
Max Loss = Worst case across all stress scenarios
practical_rules: Run stress tests before entering every position - know max loss upfront
Test worst realistic scenario: what happened in 2008, 2020, other crashes?
Position size so worst-case loss < 2-5% of account value
Re-stress test daily if position has grown to >10% of portfolio
Create 'kill switch' rules: if scenario X happens, auto-exit position
risk_warnings: Greeks-based approximations break down in extreme moves - use full revaluation
Correlation shocks: all positions may move together in crisis, compounding losses
Liquidity evaporation: in stress scenarios, bid-ask spreads widen massively
Gap risk can't be hedged - overnight moves may blow through stop losses

chunks.content: Rolling involves closing an existing option position and simultaneously opening a new position with different strike, expiration, or both. Rolling extends duration, adjusts strikes for changing market, or locks in profits while maintaining exposure. Common rolls: (1) Roll out - same strike, later expiration. Used when trade is profitable but not ready to exit, or losing trade needs more time. (2) Roll up/down - different strike, same/later expiration. Adjusts for stock price movement. (3) Roll for credit - close current position, open new position for net credit. Professional traders roll at 21 DTE or 50% max profit, whichever comes first. Why? Theta decay is non-linear - last 21 days carries gamma risk that outweighs remaining theta collection. Rolling locks in 50% gains and redeploys capital more efficiently. Adjusting is defensive - trade is losing or market structure changed. Adjust by: (1) Adding legs to convert undefined risk to defined (short call becomes call spread). (2) Widening or narrowing strikes. (3) Converting strategy type (strangle becomes iron condor). Key principle: never 'hope and pray' - have adjustment rules defined before entering trade.
key_formulas: Roll Credit/Debit = Premium Collected (new position) - Premium Paid (close old)
Effective Cost Basis after Roll = Original Cost + Roll Debit (or - Roll Credit)
Days Extended = New DTE - Old DTE
practical_rules: Roll credit spreads at 21 DTE or 50% max profit to maximize risk-adjusted returns
Roll losing positions only if thesis unchanged - don't throw good money after bad
When rolling out for credit, ensure credit received > theta you would collect holding
Adjust undefined risk positions (naked calls/puts) before they reach tested side
Never roll just before earnings/events - volatility skew will crush roll credit
risk_warnings: Rolling losers extends exposure to failed thesis - sometimes better to take loss
Roll credits can be 'negative gamma trap' - small credit, large new risk
Frequent rolling increases transaction costs - factor commissions into decision
Rolling into low liquidity expirations (non-standard dates) creates exit problems

chunks.topic: Entry Criteria for Each Strategy Type
chunks.content: Every option strategy has optimal entry conditions. Entering randomly guarantees mediocre results. (1) Credit spreads (bull put, bear call): Enter when IV rank > 50%, sell 30-45 DTE, 1 standard deviation OTM strikes (0.30-0.35 delta short strike). Collect minimum 1/3 width of spread as credit. (2) Debit spreads: Enter when IV rank < 50%, buy ATM, sell OTM 1 standard deviation away. Target 1:2 risk/reward minimum. (3) Iron condors: IV rank > 70%, 30-45 DTE, sell at 0.16 delta (1 standard deviation), collect 1/3 width as credit. (4) Straddles/strangles: Buy when IV < 30th percentile with catalyst ahead. Sell when IV > 80th percentile with no catalyst. (5) Calendars: Enter when term structure is normal/inverted, sell elevated IV front month, buy normal IV back month. ATM strikes. (6) Ratio spreads: Enter when skew is steep, vega-neutral construction. The unifying principle: match strategy to current market regime (IV level, term structure, skew). Don't force trades - wait for optimal conditions. A month with zero entries is better than entering with poor odds.
key_formulas: IV Rank = (Current IV - 52w Low IV) / (52w High IV - 52w Low IV) × 100
Delta for 1 std dev OTM ≈ 0.16 (2 std dev ≈ 0.05)
Minimum Credit (spreads) = Width of Spread / 3
practical_rules: NEVER enter credit spreads when IV rank < 30% - premium too thin
NEVER enter debit spreads when IV rank > 70% - paying for vol that will crush
Wait for IV to hit your threshold - patience is edge
Use alerts/scanners to identify optimal entries - don't browse hoping to find them
Check earnings calendar - never enter 2 weeks before earnings unless that's the strategy
risk_warnings: Optimal conditions can stay suboptimal for months - don't force trades
IV can be elevated for good reason (pending catalyst) - context matters
Missing trades is better than bad trades - opportunity cost < actual losses
Entry criteria should be objective rules, not discretionary 'feels right'

chunks.content: Exit discipline separates profitable traders from losers. Without pre-defined exits, emotions drive decisions. Standard exit rules: (1) Time-based: Exit credit spreads/iron condors at 21 DTE regardless of P/L. Remaining theta doesn't justify gamma/pin risk. (2) Profit-based: Close at 50% max profit for credit spreads. Example: sold spread for $1.00 credit, close when it hits $0.50. Statistics show 50% capture optimizes win rate × average win. Going for 80-90% max profit increases loss frequency more than it increases profit per trade. (3) Loss-based: Hard stop at 2x-3x max profit. If you collected $1.00 credit (max profit), stop out if it goes to $2.00-3.00 debit. Prevents catastrophic losses. (4) Volatility-based: Exit if IV regime changes dramatically against you. Long volatility positions exit if IV spikes (lock in gains) or if implied > realized for extended period (cutting losses). (5) Delta-based: For directional positions, exit when delta threshold hit. Example: long call, exit if delta drops below 0.30 (losing directional conviction).
key_formulas: Profit Target = Entry Credit × 0.50 (for credit spreads)
Stop Loss = Entry Credit × -2.0 to -3.0
Expected Value = (Win Rate × Avg Win) - (Loss Rate × Avg Loss)
Optimize: EV is often maximized at 50% profit target, not 100%
practical_rules: ALWAYS close credit spreads at 50% max profit - no exceptions
Set GTC orders immediately after entry: profit target and stop loss
Exit time spreads/calendars at 7-10 DTE on front month - gamma explodes
Trail stops on winning directional trades - lock in gains as position moves in your favor
If adjustment needed (2x adjustment), consider exiting instead - thesis failed
risk_warnings: Greed (waiting for 100% max profit) destroys option sellers - take 50% and move on
Hope (not stopping out losers) causes catastrophic losses - stop loss is mandatory
Weekend risk: consider closing Friday if position near tested strike
Early assignment can happen anytime on ITM short options - monitor closely

chunks.content: Stop losses in options are different from stocks due to volatility and Greeks dynamics. (1) For credit spreads: Stop at 2-3x initial credit. If you sold for $1.00 credit, stop at $2.00-3.00 loss. This gives 2:1 or 3:1 reward/risk. With 60% win rate and 2:1 R/R, you're profitable: (0.60 × 1.00) - (0.40 × 2.00) = -0.20 per trade. Need >66% win rate or better R/R. Adjust accordingly. (2) For debit spreads: Stop at loss of initial debit (100% loss) or when delta deteriorates. Don't let small debits become zeros. (3) For long options: Stop when delta drops below 0.25 or when option loses 50% of value if no catalyst imminent. Options can go to zero - protect capital. (4) For short straddles/strangles: Stop at 2x credit or when position delta exceeds ±0.50 (losing neutrality). (5) For calendars: Stop when front month has 10 DTE if losing - remaining theta doesn't justify risk. Critical rule: stops must be pre-defined and honored. No 'waiting for bounce' or 'giving it more room'. Violated stop loss discipline causes 90% of retail trader blowups.
key_formulas: Credit Spread Stop = Entry Credit × -2.0 to -3.0
Debit Spread Stop = Initial Debit (100% loss) or -50% whichever first
Win Rate Required (break even) = Loss per trade / (Win per trade + Loss per trade)
Example: 2:1 R/R requires 66.7% win rate to break even
practical_rules: Enter stop loss order immediately after trade entry - no discretion later
For spreads, use 'stop market' not 'stop limit' - ensure execution in fast markets
Trail stops on winners - raise stop to break-even after 25% profit
Mental stops don't work - human psychology fails under pressure
If you hit stop 3 times in a row on same setup, pause and re-evaluate strategy
risk_warnings: Gap moves blow through stops - overnight risk can't be fully hedged
Low liquidity can cause stop to execute at much worse price than expected
Stop hunting happens at obvious levels - use non-round-number stops
Emotions will tell you to wait 'just a little longer' - ignore and execute stop

chunks.content: American options can be exercised anytime, creating assignment risk for option sellers. Understanding when early exercise is likely prevents surprises. (1) Calls exercised early: Deep ITM calls before ex-dividend date. Option holder exercises to capture dividend rather than lose stock value at ex-date. Monitor any short calls ITM approaching ex-dividend. (2) Puts exercised early: Deep ITM puts in high interest rate environments. Put holder exercises to receive cash proceeds and earn interest rather than wait. Less common than call assignment but happens. (3) Assignment mechanics: If you're short an option and it's exercised, you're assigned. Short call → forced to sell 100 shares at strike (even if you don't own them = short stock position). Short put → forced to buy 100 shares at strike. Assignment happens overnight after market close. You wake up with stock position. (4) Pin risk: At expiration, if stock closes exactly at a strike you're short, you don't know if you'll be assigned. Some contracts will be, others won't. This creates undefined position over weekend. (5) Avoiding assignment: Close ITM short options before expiration rather than hoping they expire worthless. The last $0.05-0.10 of value isn't worth assignment risk.
key_formulas: ITM Call Assignment Risk = (Strike - Stock Price + Dividend) / Option Price
If (Dividend - Time Value) > 0, early exercise likely
Time Value = Option Price - Intrinsic Value
practical_rules: Close short options if ITM >$1.00 with ex-dividend in next 2 days
Don't hold ITM short options through expiration - close at 3:50 PM
If assigned, immediately decide: close stock position or keep for directional play
Monitor margin requirements - stock assignment requires more capital than option
Set alerts for options going ITM so you can close before assignment risk peaks
risk_warnings: Weekend assignment risk: assigned Friday evening, can't trade until Monday morning
Short call assignment creates short stock position - unlimited risk if not covered
Dividend capture assignment is common - don't be surprised by ITM calls before ex-date
Pin risk at expiration can create 0-100 share random positions - avoid by closing early

chunks.topic: Natenberg's Key Trading Principles - Professional Mindset
chunks.content: Sheldon Natenberg emphasizes several core principles that separate professional option traders from amateurs: (1) Theoretical edge: Always know the theoretical value of your position. If you can't calculate it, don't trade it. Use models (Black-Scholes, binomial) to establish fair value, then trade when market price diverges. (2) Risk management over prediction: You can't consistently predict market direction. You CAN consistently manage risk through position sizing, stops, and hedging. Focus on the latter. (3) Volatility is mean-reverting: The most reliable phenomenon in options markets. Trade the extremes - sell expensive volatility, buy cheap volatility. Be patient waiting for extremes. (4) Time is your enemy or friend: Long options fight time decay every day. Short options collect it. Choose strategies that align with your outlook on both direction AND time. (5) Know your Greeks: Before every trade, explicitly state your delta, gamma, theta, vega exposures. If you can't explain what you're betting on, don't place the bet. (6) Liquidity matters: Tight bid-ask spreads are more important than finding the 'perfect' setup. Wide markets destroy profitability through slippage. (7) Probability thinking: Think in terms of expected value and win rates, not individual trade outcomes.
key_formulas: Expected Value = Σ(Probability_i × Outcome_i)
Theoretical Edge = Fair Value - Market Price
Risk-Adjusted Return = Expected Value / Capital at Risk
practical_rules: Calculate theoretical value for every position before entry - use online calculators if needed
Never risk more than 2% of account on any single position
Focus 80% of effort on risk management, 20% on trade selection
Trade only highly liquid options - minimum 1000 open interest, $0.05-0.10 bid-ask spread
Review Greeks weekly, ask: 'Am I exposed to risks I don't intend to take?'
risk_warnings: Overconfidence in theoretical models - models are wrong, markets are right
Ignoring transaction costs - commissions and slippage compound over many trades
Trading too frequently - every trade has edge erosion from spreads
Focusing solely on winners - risk management prevents catastrophic losses that wipe out wins
